history.content: It's because they're reserved for certain categories that have priority through the adjustment period. Once class starts and the delegated seats are open, they will be filled.
It's because they're reserved for certain categories that have priority through the adjustment period. Once class starts and the delegated seats are open, they will be filled.
Unfortunately, it is looking possible (although not certain) that the budget will not exist to enroll over 500 students into 188 for spring 16.

children.subject: You should make backup plans now in case it doesn't turn out optimally.  Right now the answer is no and will probably stay that way but people are trying to find additional solutions.  If nothing changes by the end of the second week of classes, it certainly won't change afterward.  Every day between now and then that enrollment stays at around 500, makes it less likely that anything else will become possible.
If I withdraw from the semester before the end of the second week of classes can I get a refund on tuition?

I understand that it would be hard to give a concrete answer, but if I'm 195 on the waitlist for 188, should I still attend class for 188 up until the second week, or would it be more advantageous to drop it?
Unless you're up at a unit cap it makes sense to say with the class AND enroll in a backup. But that means you're doing double work for up to 5 weeks. :/
@ 2nd anonymous post: I believe http://registrar.berkeley.edu/canwd.html#refsched answers your question.
So to be practical, I suppose I will have to make up my mind whether or not to withdraw by Jan29. By that time I should know if I can get in 188 or not. Is this correct?
Likely but not definitely. We will continue to enroll to account for attrition though the morning of February 8.

That was my understanding. Keep in mind people can add / drop through the 5th week. (Unless 188 is different). So if you're not super far down the list at that point you still have a chance of getting in. :)

I guess it all depends on the class but I've jumped 60 spots on the 186 list in the past weeks.

For cs upper div classes, we front load enrollments which means we enroll to slightly above actual teaching capacity but finalize enrollments the Monday after the 3rd week of classes (eg the morning of Feb 8 for SP16).  If a student isn't enrolled in an upper div cs class by noon on that day, then they won't be enrolled in that class in the current semester.  The drops that happen in week 4 and 5 right-size the class so that faculty and gsi's can teach.  The goal (and usual result) is that we enroll the same # of people as we would have otherwise but we let people know earlier.  One hope is that this lowers stress for students who do make it in (who find out more quickly) and gives students who weren't going to be able to be accommodated less time to have to do multiple classes work while they are finalizing their schedule.

Thanks! That makes sense.  

Would it be possible to add that info to this page: 

http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/Policies/enrollment.shtml

And maybe someone should let the L&S office link to that page? There's lots of ambiguities about add drop deadlines.
Ok, thanks! So if I don't get in by the third week, I can safely assume that I won't be getting into 188 at all, and should drop it?

Does the department know how much they screw students over by first "expanding" the capacity to 700+ students and then contracting it back? I dropped a class when I heard it was expanded to waitlist myself, and now can't go back since that class is full too -- not to mention the majority of CS courses and even some EE courses are beyond full at this point too... I understand that there aren't enough resources but why would you expand capacity in the first place unless you aren't sure. I'm seriously considering withdrawing this semester too now
Used my phase 2 units on 188 and 186, still on the waitlist for both classes. There is no practical backup plan at this point...

Michael had a good idea and I've put it on my list for things to do after the rush of the beginning of the semester.  

Look, I understand some of the frustration but the department --just like everyone else -- acts on the best information we have at any given time.  A waitlist is exactly that -- by definition it means you are not yet enrolled in a particular course and have no guarantees of being enrolled.  While we wish we could accommodate everyone, its just not always possible.  I believe the policy here does a good job of prioritizing access to students in our majors (whom we've made implicit promises that you will be able to graduate on time) especially for students who plan well and through their planning show us that it is a priority for that particular student to take a particular class: see http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/Policies/enrollment.shtml  .

There are indeed courses now that could be used as backups. Courses like 162, EECS 151, CS152, 164, 172 and 174 are worth looking into as are many EE courses and technical electives (see https://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/csugrad/tech_electives ).
Each TA is assigned two sections right? So to accommodate 200 more students, the CS department would only have to hire 4 more TAs.

It's a bit more complicated than that, but that's close enough. But each TAs who teach 2 sections, is $16K/semester * 4, starts to add up. Additionally, there's the scheduling demands, of find ~7 more sections and an at least somewhat bigger lecture hall. (At this point you only have 3 rooms on campus, and one is out of commission...)

Not that I don't agree that it sucks! :( just, there's not tons people can do.
*Willing to donate to a TA hiring fund if I can get into the class*
When will we know for sure if the budget will allow or not?

history.subject: why are there still so many open seats for 188?
